Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing Secondary Gravity Waves and Influences on Momentum Transport
Award.AbstractNarration: This project would carry out research primarily aimed at the study of the production and effects of secondary gravity waves (SGWs). The main objective is to understand how breaking gravity waves produce SGWs and then to assess the subsequent effect of SGWs on the mesosphere and lower thermosphere region. Studying the process of developing SGWs is necessary because these waves would potentially transport momentum to higher altitudes than the primary GW. The science plan of this project would also consider whether some of these SGWs could propagate even through a critical layer. These are important aspects of the coupling processes between different atmospheric layers. This question of energy transfer between atmospheric regions is a potentially transformative area of research and is an active topic in atmospheric research now that observations and models have recently become available. This project would help support two early career researchers with the lead Principal Investigator (PI) being a woman thus improving the gender diversity within the space physics community.<br/><br/>While theory and modeling demonstrate the presence of secondary gravity waves, there are few observational, statistical, and combined modeling and observational studies on SGW generation and associated momentum flux and influences within the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region. The research aims to answer the following questions: 1) How do stratospheric and mesospheric conditions play a role in the evolution and propagation of gravity waves into the MLT and the progression of breaking conditions leading to SGW generation? 2) What are the implications of gravity wave breaking and resulting secondary gravity waves on momentum transport in the MLT? 3) What is the correlation between strong orographic gravity wave activity observed in the Northern hemisphere and observations of different gravity wave spectra in the MLT?<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric gravity waves, also called buoyancy waves, are much like waves in the ocean. These waves propagate upwards throughout the atmosphere, perturbing winds, temperatures, and densities, while also carrying momentum. When these gravity waves break, they cause drag on background mean winds, and subsequently generate new gravity waves that can propagate to even higher altitudes. This multi-step coupling process has the potential to cause significant variations in the thermosphere and ionosphere region of Earth where low Earth orbit satellites exist. 

The results of this project demonstrated the influence that the lower atmosphere has on variability in the thermosphere/ionosphere region. This project investigated gravity wave propagation into the mesosphere and thermosphere under various stratospheric and mesospheric conditions. There was specific focus on gravity wave breaking and the generation of secondary gravity waves that propagated to higher altitudes into the thermosphere/ionosphere region. One of the stratospheric influences studied was the polar night jet, a region of strong winds in the polar stratospheric region. Results from this research demonstrated that the polar night jet is not only a source of secondary gravity waves generated from orographic wave breaking on the top side of the jet, but also a source of primary gravity waves that break at higher altitudes [Bossert et al., 2020; Becker et al., 2022]. Modeling research from this project also demonstrated that gravity waves generated in the region of the polar vortex will be filtered by the semidiurnal tide in the lower thermosphere, and their influence on the thermosphere changes depending on the phase of the semi-diurnal tide in this region [Heale et al., 2020]. Additional research from this project found that variability in the thermosphere due to wave perturbations during geomagnetically quiet times is linked to variability in the polar night jet. Another condition under which secondary gravity waves were studied was during the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’api volcanic eruption. Model studies from HIAMCM demonstrated that many observed gravity waves after the eruption were secondary gravity waves generated from breaking primary gravity waves generated from the eruption. These non-primary gravity waves were observed at altitudes in the thermosphere.
